Package ohos.utils.net

Class Uri

  • java.lang.Object
    • ohos.utils.net.Uri
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Comparable<Uri>, Sequenceable

    public abstract class Uri
extends Object
implements Sequenceable, Comparable<Uri>
    Helps to construct and parse a Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) based on RFC 2396.

    For details, see RFC 2396.

    The standard URI format is as follows:

    [scheme:]scheme-specific-part[#fragment]

    As described in RFC 2396, URIs are classified into four types: hierarchical, opaque, relative, and absolute URIs.

    Since:
    1

    • Method Detail

      • isHierarchical

        public abstract boolean isHierarchical​()
        Checks whether the current URI is a hierarchical one.

        For example, http://www.huawei.com. A hierarchical URI can be an absolute one, but its scheme-specific-part field must start with a slash (/). It can also be a relative one.

        Returns:
        Returns true if it is a hierarchical URI; returns false otherwise.

      • isOpaque

        public boolean isOpaque​()
        Checks whether the current URI is an opaque one.

        For example, news:www.huawei.com. An opaque URI must be an absolute URI and its scheme-specific-part field cannot start with a slash (/).

        Returns:
        Returns true if it is an opaque URI; returns false otherwise.

      • isRelative

        public boolean isRelative​()
        Checks whether the current URI is a relative one.

        For example, www.huawei.com. A relative URI does not contain the scheme field.

        Returns:
        Returns true if it is a relative URI; returns false otherwise.

      • isAbsolute

        public boolean isAbsolute​()
        Checks whether the current URI is an absolute one.

        For example, http://www.huawei.com. An absolute URI must contain the scheme field.

        Returns:
        Returns true if it is an absolute URI; returns false otherwise.

      • getScheme

        public String getScheme​()
        Obtains the scheme field of the current URI.

        For example, http is the scheme field of URI http://www.huawei.com.

        Returns:
        Returns the scheme field; returns null if the current URI does not contain the scheme field.

      • getDecodedSchemeSpecificPart

        public abstract String getDecodedSchemeSpecificPart​()
        Obtains the decoded scheme-specific-part field in the current URI.

        It is everything between the scheme separator (:) and the fragment separator (#).

        For example, in URI https://www.huawei.com/cn/?ic_medium=direct, //www.huawei.com/cn/?ic_medium=direct is the scheme-specific-part field.

        Returns:
        Returns the decoded scheme-specific-part field; returns null if the current URI does not contain the scheme-specific-part field.

      • getEncodedSchemeSpecificPart

        public abstract String getEncodedSchemeSpecificPart​()
        Obtains the encoded scheme-specific-part field in the current URI.
        Returns:
        Returns the encoded scheme-specific-part field; returns null if the current URI does not contain the scheme-specific-part field.
        See Also:
        getDecodedSchemeSpecificPart()

      • getDecodedAuthority

        public abstract String getDecodedAuthority​()
        Obtains the decoded authority field of the current URI.

        A hierarchical URI is in the format of [scheme:][//authority][path][?query][#fragment]. For example, www.huawei.com is the authority field of URI https://www.huawei.com/cn/?ic_medium=direct.

        Returns:
        Returns the decoded authority field; returns null if the current URI does not contain the authority field.

      • getEncodedAuthority

        public abstract String getEncodedAuthority​()
        Obtains the encoded authority field of the current URI.
        Returns:
        Returns the encoded authority field; returns null if the current URI does not contain the authority field.
        See Also:
        getDecodedAuthority()

      • getDecodedUserInfo

        public abstract String getDecodedUserInfo​()
        Obtains the decoded user-info field of the current URI.

        The authority structure of the server type is in the format of [user-info@]host[:port].

        For example, test is the user-info field of the authority structure test@huawei.com.

        Returns:
        Returns the decoded user-info field; returns null if the current URI does not contain the user-info field.

        getDecodedUserInfo()

        public abstract String getDecodedHost​()
        Obtains the decoded host field of the current URI.

        The authority structure of the server type is in the format of [user-info@]host[:port].

        For example, huawei.com is the host field of the authority structure test@huawei.com.

        Returns:
        Returns the decoded host field; returns null if the current URI does not contain the host field.

      • getPort

        public abstract int getPort​()
        Obtains the port field of the current URI.

        The authority structure of the server type is in the format of [user-info@]host[:port].

        For example, 443 is the port field of the authority structure test@huawei.com:443.

        Returns:
        Returns the port field of the current URI; returns -1 if the current URI does not contain the port field.

      • getDecodedPathList

        public abstract List<String> getDecodedPathList​()
        Obtains a list of decoded paths in the current URI.

        There may be multiple path fields in a URI, for example, scheme://authority/path1/path2/path3?query#fragment.

        Returns:
        Returns the list of decoded paths; returns an empty list if no path is available.

      • getDecodedQuery

        public abstract String getDecodedQuery​()
        Obtains the decoded query field in the current URI.

        It is everything between the query separator (?) and the fragment separator (#). For example, ic_medium=direct is the query field of URI https://www.huawei.com/cn/?ic_medium=direct.

        Returns:
        Returns the decoded query field; returns null if the current URI does not contain the query field.

      • getDecodedQueryParams

        public abstract Map<String,List<String>> getDecodedQueryParams​()
        Obtains all search criteria and values in the query field of the current URI.
        Returns:
        Returns a map of all search criteria. The map consists of search criterion names (referred to as key) and search criterion values (referred to as value). The values in the map are in the same sequence as the query statements of the URI. Returns a map containing "" if the specified key has no value associated.

      • getDecodedFragment

        public abstract String getDecodedFragment​()
        Obtains the decoded fragment field of the current URI.

        For example, 28 is the fragment field of URI https://www.huawei.com/cn/?ic_medium=direct#28.

        Returns:
        Returns the decoded fragment field; returns null if the current URI does not contain the fragment field.

      • encode

        public static String encode​(String str)
        Encodes the specified string using UTF-8 encoding.

        All characters, except letters (A-Z and a-z), digits 0-9, and non-reserved characters ("_-!.~'()*") can be encoded.

        Parameters:
        str - Indicates the string to encode.
        Returns:
        Returns the encoded string; returns null if null is passed in the input parameter.

      • encode

        public static String encode​(String str,
                            String allow)
        Encodes the characters other than those specified by the allow parameter using UTF-8 encoding.

        Letters (A-Z and a-z), digits 0-9, and non-reserved characters ("_-!.~'()*") will not be encoded.

        Parameters:
        str - Indicates the string to encode.
        allow - Indicates the additional character set that will not be encoded. You can set it to null.
        Returns:
        Returns the encoded string; returns null if null is passed in the input parameter.

      • getQueryParamsByKey

        public List<String> getQueryParamsByKey​(String key)
        Obtains all results that match the query field in the current URI based on a specified key.

        Keys can be duplicate and may have no values associated. Therefore, a list of matched results is returned in the sequence of statements in the query field. If the specified key exists but has no value associated, a list containing "" will be returned.

        Parameters:
        key - Indicates the decoded key.
        Returns:
        Returns all matched decoded results sorted in the sequence of statements in the query field of the URI; returns an empty list if no result is found.

      • getFirstQueryParamByKey

        public String getFirstQueryParamByKey​(String key)
        Obtains the first result that matches the query field in the current URI based on a specified key.

        Keys can be duplicate and may have no values associated. Therefore, the first matched result is returned in the sequence of statements in the query field. If the specified key has no value, "" will be returned.

        Parameters:
        key - Indicates the decoded key.
        Returns:
        Returns the first matched decoded result; returns "" if no result is found.

      • getQueryParamNames

        public Set<String> getQueryParamNames​()
        Obtains all names in the query field of the current URI.
        Returns:
        Returns all names in the decoded query field of the current URI; returns an empty list if there is no query field.

      • getBooleanQueryParam

        public boolean getBooleanQueryParam​(String key,
                                    boolean defaultValue)
        Obtains the first result that matches the query field in the current URI based on a specified key and checks whether the result is not false or 0.
        Parameters:
        key - Indicates the decoded key.
        defaultValue - Indicates the default value to return if no result is found.
        Returns:
        Returns defaultValue if no match is found; returns false if the matched value is false or 0; returns true for other cases.

        Sets the scheme field in the current Uri object to lowercase.
        Returns:
        Returns a Uri object with the scheme field in lowercase.

      • equals

        public boolean equals​(Object obj)
        Description copied from class: Object
        Indicates whether some other object is "equal to" this one.

        The equals method implements an equivalence relation on non-null object references:

        • It is reflexive: for any non-null reference value x, x.equals(x) should return true.
        • It is symmetric: for any non-null reference values x and y, x.equals(y) should return true if and only if y.equals(x) returns true.
        • It is transitive: for any non-null reference values x, y, and z, if x.equals(y) returns true and y.equals(z) returns true, then x.equals(z) should return true.
        • It is consistent: for any non-null reference values x and y, multiple invocations of x.equals(y) consistently return true or consistently return false, provided no information used in equals comparisons on the objects is modified.
        • For any non-null reference value x, x.equals(null) should return false.

        The equals method for class Object implements the most discriminating possible equivalence relation on objects; that is, for any non-null reference values x and y, this method returns true if and only if x and y refer to the same object (x == y has the value true).

        Note that it is generally necessary to override the hashCode method whenever this method is overridden, so as to maintain the general contract for the hashCode method, which states that equal objects must have equal hash codes.

        Overrides:
        equals in class Object
        Parameters:
        obj - the reference object with which to compare.
        Returns:
        true if this object is the same as the obj argument; false otherwise.
        See Also:
        Object.hashCode(), HashMap

      • hashCode

        public int hashCode​()
        Description copied from class: Object
        Returns a hash code value for the object. This method is supported for the benefit of hash tables such as those provided by HashMap.

        The general contract of hashCode is:

        • Whenever it is invoked on the same object more than once during an execution of a Java application, the hashCode method must consistently return the same integer, provided no information used in equals comparisons on the object is modified. This integer need not remain consistent from one execution of an application to another execution of the same application.
        • If two objects are equal according to the equals(Object) method, then calling the hashCode method on each of the two objects must produce the same integer result.
        • It is not required that if two objects are unequal according to the Object.equals(java.lang.Object) method, then calling the hashCode method on each of the two objects must produce distinct integer results. However, the programmer should be aware that producing distinct integer results for unequal objects may improve the performance of hash tables.

        As much as is reasonably practical, the hashCode method defined by class Object does return distinct integers for distinct objects. (This is typically implemented by converting the internal address of the object into an integer, but this implementation technique is not required by the Java™ programming language.)

        Overrides:
        hashCode in class Object
        Returns:
        a hash code value for this object.
        See Also:
        Object.equals(java.lang.Object), System.identityHashCode(java.lang.Object)

      • compareTo

        public int compareTo​(Uri other)
        Description copied from interface: Comparable
        Compares this object with the specified object for order. Returns a negative integer, zero, or a positive integer as this object is less than, equal to, or greater than the specified object.

        The implementor must ensure sgn(x.compareTo(y)) == -sgn(y.compareTo(x)) for all x and y. (This implies that x.compareTo(y) must throw an exception iff y.compareTo(x) throws an exception.)

        The implementor must also ensure that the relation is transitive: (x.compareTo(y)>0 && y.compareTo(z)>0) implies x.compareTo(z)>0.

        Finally, the implementor must ensure that x.compareTo(y)==0 implies that sgn(x.compareTo(z)) == sgn(y.compareTo(z)), for all z.

        It is strongly recommended, but not strictly required that (x.compareTo(y)==0) == (x.equals(y)). Generally speaking, any class that implements the Comparable interface and violates this condition should clearly indicate this fact. The recommended language is "Note: this class has a natural ordering that is inconsistent with equals."

        In the foregoing description, the notation sgn(expression) designates the mathematical signum function, which is defined to return one of -1, 0, or 1 according to whether the value of expression is negative, zero or positive.

        Specified by:
        compareTo in interface Comparable<Uri>
        Parameters:
        other - the object to be compared.
        Returns:
        a negative integer, zero, or a positive integer as this object is less than, equal to, or greater than the specified object.

      • hasFileDescriptor

        public boolean hasFileDescriptor​()
        Description copied from interface: Sequenceable
        Checks whether the implementation class of this Sequenceable contains FileDescriptor object data.

        If the custom Sequenceable class contains any FileDescriptor data, you should override this method. This method return false by default.

        Specified by:
        hasFileDescriptor in interface Sequenceable
        Returns:
        Returns true if it contains FileDescriptor data; returns false otherwise.
